elements.clean_text:
Table 3

The comparison of obtained Nd fumarates and maleates – crystal structure data.[^a]

|                               | Fumarate | Maleate[^a] |
|-------------------------------|----------|-------------|
| Crystal system                | triclinic| triclinic   |
| space group                   | P1¯      | P1¯         |
| Coordination number           | 9        | 9           |
| Number of carboxyl oxygen coordinating to the Ln ion | 6 | 2 |
| Number of water molecules coordinating to the Ln ion | 3 | 7 |
| Average Nd–O distance (Å)     | 2.513    | 2.503       |

[^a]: [12].

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
The complexation of trivalent lanthanides with fumaric acid was studied. The spectroscopic investigations were performed and crystal structures were solved for Ln2(C4O4H2)3·8H2O (Ln=Sm, Eu, Nd) and Er2(C4O4H2)3·12H2O. In all four crystals, 3-dimensional polymeric structures are formed. In the emission spectra at 293K and 77K, peaks correspond to four J levels of the 6H
J
 term, and these transitions split at 77K indicating a low symmetry of the Sm3+ ion. The most intense transition in UV–Vis is the hypersensitive 4G5/2
→
6H9/2 transition, and the I(4G5/2
→
6H9/2)/I(4G5/2
→
6H5/2) (η
Sm) ratio was calculated.

<ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">The complexation of trivalent lanthanides with fumaric acid was studied. Monocrystals of Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Sm, Eu, Nd) and Er<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were formed during the slow evaporation of appropriate aqueous solutions. The spectroscopic investigations were performed for samarium(III) fumarate, and the crystal structures were solved for the samarium(III) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), europium(III) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), neodymium(III) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and erbium(III) (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) complexes. It was found that the Nd, Eu, and Sm fumarates were isostructural (space group <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>
<mml:mover accent="true">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>¯</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mover>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>), but the Er compound was different (space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>). In the three former crystals, there is one symmetry-independent Ln(III) cation, which adopts a 9-coordinate geometry with six oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups and three oxygen atoms from water molecules. In the Er(III) complex, the metal ion is eight-coordinated (six atoms from the fumarate carboxyl groups and two water molecules). In all four crystals, 3-dimensional polymeric structures are formed. For Sm(III) fumarate, electronic (absorption and emission) spectra were recorded at room and low temperatures. In the emission spectra at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, peaks correspond to four <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> levels of the <ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">J</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> term (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2), and these transitions split at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K indicating the low symmetry of the Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion. The most intense transition in UV–Vis is the hypersensitive <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">9/2</ce:inf> transition, and the I(<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>

<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">9/2</ce:inf>)/I(<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>) (<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text:
Abstract
The complexation of trivalent lanthanides with fumaric acid was studied. Monocrystals of Ln2(C4O4H2)3·8H2O (Ln=Sm, Eu, Nd) and Er2(C4O4H2)3·12H2O were formed during the slow evaporation of appropriate aqueous solutions. The spectroscopic investigations were performed for samarium(III) fumarate, and the crystal structures were solved for the samarium(III) (1), europium(III) (2), neodymium(III) (3), and erbium(III) (4) complexes. It was found that the Nd, Eu, and Sm fumarates were isostructural (space group 

P


1


¯



), but the Er compound was different (space group P21/c). In the three former crystals, there is one symmetry-independent Ln(III) cation, which adopts a 9-coordinate geometry with six oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups and three oxygen atoms from water molecules. In the Er(III) complex, the metal ion is eight-coordinated (six atoms from the fumarate carboxyl groups and two water molecules). In all four crystals, 3-dimensional polymeric structures are formed. For Sm(III) fumarate, electronic (absorption and emission) spectra were recorded at room and low temperatures. In the emission spectra at 293K and 77K, peaks correspond to four J levels of the 6H
J
 term (J
=5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2), and these transitions split at 77K indicating the low symmetry of the Sm3+ ion. The most intense transition in UV–Vis is the hypersensitive 4G5/2
→
6H9/2 transition, and the I(4G5/2
→
6H9/2)/I(4G5/2
→
6H5/2) (η
Sm) ratio was calculated.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">The nephelauxetic ratio <ce:italic>β</ce:italic> and Sinha’s parameter <ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>, calculated on the basis of the absorption spectra, suggested the decrease in the “degree of covalency” of the Sm–O bond from Sm maleate to Sm fumarate.</ce:simple-para>

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal–organic coordination systems are porous materials with applications in such fields as catalysis, luminescent materials, non-linear optics, and others. Studies of metal ion complexation with aliphatic carboxylic acids, especially containing multiple bonds, can help to interpret many other topics, such as the behavior of heavy radioactive nuclides (due to the role of humic acids) . The O-donor ligands efficiently coordinate Ln<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions yielding coordination polymers. The carboxylic group from the ligand strongly binds the lanthanide ion, giving rise to various coordination geometries around the metal cation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Metal–organic coordination systems are porous materials with applications in such fields as catalysis, luminescent materials, non-linear optics, and others. Studies of metal ion complexation with aliphatic carboxylic acids, especially containing multiple bonds, can help to interpret many other topics, such as the behavior of heavy radioactive nuclides (due to the role of humic acids) . The O-donor ligands efficiently coordinate Ln3+ ions yielding coordination polymers. The carboxylic group from the ligand strongly binds the lanthanide ion, giving rise to various coordination geometries around the metal cation.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In a previous paper, we reported the results of a study of lanthanide maleates . In this work, the structure and spectroscopy of lanthanide complexes with fumaric acid are studied. Fumaric and maleic acid are two isomers of butenodioic acid – trans- and cis-, respectively. Thus, fumarate complexes will be compared to maleates. The pK<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> values for maleic acid are pK<ce:inf loc="post">a1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.97; pK<ce:inf loc="post">a2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.07, and for fumaric acid, pK<ce:inf loc="post">a1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.03 and pK<ce:inf loc="post">a2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.44. The comparison of these values, especially pK<ce:inf loc="post">a1</ce:inf> values and the differences between pK<ce:inf loc="post">a1</ce:inf> and pK<ce:inf loc="post">a2</ce:inf> values for both acids, indicates why we obtained the complexes of the Ln-hydrogenmaleate ion and the Ln-fumarate ion. Thus, the coordination forms differ for both ligands, which can be seen in the crystallography data and in the spectroscopic properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
In a previous paper, we reported the results of a study of lanthanide maleates . In this work, the structure and spectroscopy of lanthanide complexes with fumaric acid are studied. Fumaric and maleic acid are two isomers of butenodioic acid – trans- and cis-, respectively. Thus, fumarate complexes will be compared to maleates. The pKa values for maleic acid are pKa1
=1.97; pKa2
=6.07, and for fumaric acid, pKa1
=3.03 and pKa2
=4.44. The comparison of these values, especially pKa1 values and the differences between pKa1 and pKa2 values for both acids, indicates why we obtained the complexes of the Ln-hydrogenmaleate ion and the Ln-fumarate ion. Thus, the coordination forms differ for both ligands, which can be seen in the crystallography data and in the spectroscopic properties.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Double bonds are groups which can indirectly influence increasing of the luminescence of lanthanide ions. Thus, it is interesting to find new ligand–metal interactions.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Here, we report on the crystallographic investigations of Sm(III), Er(III), Nd(III), and Eu(III) fumarates and the spectroscopic measurements of absorption, emission, and excitation for Sm(III) fumarate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Double bonds are groups which can indirectly influence increasing of the luminescence of lanthanide ions. Thus, it is interesting to find new ligand–metal interactions.
Here, we report on the crystallographic investigations of Sm(III), Er(III), Nd(III), and Eu(III) fumarates and the spectroscopic measurements of absorption, emission, and excitation for Sm(III) fumarate.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Since fumaric acid, unlike maleic acid, is hardly soluble in water (solubility in water is 0.63<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g/100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 78<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g/100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, respectively), the syntheses could not be performed in a way similar to that applied for Ln(III) maleates ; instead, we used freshly prepared water solutions of sodium maleate and Ln(III) nitrates. We declined to change the solvent, because we tried to have as similar conditions to the previous ones as possible.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Since fumaric acid, unlike maleic acid, is hardly soluble in water (solubility in water is 0.63g/100g H2O and 78g/100g H2O, respectively), the syntheses could not be performed in a way similar to that applied for Ln(III) maleates ; instead, we used freshly prepared water solutions of sodium maleate and Ln(III) nitrates. We declined to change the solvent, because we tried to have as similar conditions to the previous ones as possible.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Commercially available chemicals were used: C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (99.5%, Loba Chemie) and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (>99.5, Sigma Aldrich). Lanthanide nitrate hydrates were obtained by treating the respective lanthanide oxide, Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (99.999%, Aldrich), with concentrated nitric acid, followed by the evaporation of excess acid.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Commercially available chemicals were used: C4H4O4 (99.5%, Loba Chemie) and Na2CO3 (>99.5, Sigma Aldrich). Lanthanide nitrate hydrates were obtained by treating the respective lanthanide oxide, Ln2O3 (99.999%, Aldrich), with concentrated nitric acid, followed by the evaporation of excess acid.

<ce:section-title id="st030">X-rays</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Appropriate crystals were cut from larger ones and mounted on a Kuma KM4 diffractometer equipped with a CCD counter. The collected data were corrected for polarization, Lorentz, and absorption effects, the last one calculated from the crystal habits captured from photo scans. The structures were solved and refined with <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>97 and <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>97 programs . The structures were also solved with the Patterson methods. The positions of the C-bonded hydrogen atoms were calculated geometrically; no attempt to localize the O-bonded H atoms was made. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of the C-bonded H atoms were geometrically constrained, and their isotropic temperature factors were constrained as 1.2 of the trace of the thermal vibration tensors of the parent C atoms. elements.clean_text:
X-rays
Appropriate crystals were cut from larger ones and mounted on a Kuma KM4 diffractometer equipped with a CCD counter. The collected data were corrected for polarization, Lorentz, and absorption effects, the last one calculated from the crystal habits captured from photo scans. The structures were solved and refined with shelxs97 and shelxl97 programs . The structures were also solved with the Patterson methods. The positions of the C-bonded hydrogen atoms were calculated geometrically; no attempt to localize the O-bonded H atoms was made. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of the C-bonded H atoms were geometrically constrained, and their isotropic temperature factors were constrained as 1.2 of the trace of the thermal vibration tensors of the parent C atoms. The pertinent data are given in 
.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st035">Spectroscopic measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">High-resolution absorption spectra of single crystals of samarium(III) fumarate were recorded within the spectral range 250–1600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm at 293 and 4.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K using a Cary-Varian 500 UV–Vis–near-IR spectrophotometer equipped with an Oxford CF 1204 continuous-flow helium cryostat. The areas of the absorption bands were integrated graphically and expressed in terms of the oscillator strengths using the program described in our paper . The experimental oscillator strength values were used for the calculation of the Judd–Ofelt parameter .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic measurements
High-resolution absorption spectra of single crystals of samarium(III) fumarate were recorded within the spectral range 250–1600nm at 293 and 4.2K using a Cary-Varian 500 UV–Vis–near-IR spectrophotometer equipped with an Oxford CF 1204 continuous-flow helium cryostat. The areas of the absorption bands were integrated graphically and expressed in terms of the oscillator strengths using the program described in our paper . The experimental oscillator strength values were used for the calculation of the Judd–Ofelt parameter .

A 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>W xenon lamp was used as an excitation source.</ce:para>

The IR spectra were measured in KBr pellets (4000–500cm−1) and as Nujol suspension on polyethylene windows (500–50cm−1) with a Bruker IFS 66 spectrophotometer.
Results and discussion
X-ray crystallography
Three of the presented compounds, neodymium(III), samarium(III), and europium(III) fumarates, are isomorphous. The lanthanide cation in these structures is 9-coordinate, and its first coordination sphere is composed of six carboxylate oxygen atoms and three water molecules; see 
 for the Ln–O distances. There are three symmetry independent fumarate anions, with inversion centers located in their double CC bonds. Each of the anions forms a different bonding pattern with the metal cations; for the sake of convenience the fumarates will be labeled after their carboxylate carbon atoms. Thus, each carboxyl group from the C1 anion is involved in chelate bridging-bidentate μ(O,O′:O) coordination to two metal cations. In this way, this anion links four lanthanide cations. The C3 ligand also links four Ln cations, but its carboxyl groups coordinate in a bridging fashion, μ (O:O′). In the C5 anion, the carboxyl groups are monodentate. In this way, a 3-dimensional polymeric structure is formed, where molecules C1 link the polymer along the b direction, molecules C3 along a, and molecules C5 along a
+
b (the diagonal). Bonding along c is provided by bridging carboxyl groups from C1 and C3. The shortest Ln–Ln distance is approximately 4.3Å (see  for the exact values). Apart from the polymeric framework, the crystal contains crystallization water (one symmetry independent molecule per asymmetric part of the unit cell). The structure is stabilized by a network of hydrogen bonds. The coordination of Ln3+ (1, 2, 3) and the fumarate anions is shown in 
 and the crystal packing in 
.

The two carboxylate groups of the C1 anion coordinate to four Er3+ cations in a bridging fashion, μ(O:O′), whereas in the case of the C5 ligand, the –COO− groups are bonded to a single metal cation in a chelate mode. The Er3+ cation is 8-coordinate; six coordination sites are occupied by carboxylate oxygen atoms and two by water molecules. The complex is a 3-dimensional polymer. elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0085" view="all">According to the literature, the crystal structures of our compounds differ from those previously reported . A fumarate complex of europium, C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
, is monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>; both Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> cations are coordinated by nine oxygen atoms – seven from five fumaric ligands and two from water molecules, which is different from our investigations. Another monoclinic (<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>) crystal structure, a Sm(III) maleate , contains three different fumarate ligands; each has a different coordination mode of the two COO groups. Nevertheless, its crystallography system and space group are monoclinic and <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>, respectively, identical to those described above . The differences between our crystals and C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are those reported above, which were caused by the method of preparation. Our crystals were obtained from water solution at ambient conditions, while the other ones were obtained by the hydrothermal method  or in an ethanol solution . The latter ways may lead to more condensed products with fewer water component molecules. The second difference is the ligand:ion molar ratio used in the reaction – we obtained our crystals with the 3:1 ratio, while the C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> crystals were obtained at the 3:2 ratio for the hydrothermal method.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
According to the literature, the crystal structures of our compounds differ from those previously reported . A fumarate complex of europium, C12H20O19Eu2
, is monoclinic, space group P21/n; both Eu3+ cations are coordinated by nine oxygen atoms – seven from five fumaric ligands and two from water molecules, which is different from our investigations. Another monoclinic (P21/n) crystal structure, a Sm(III) maleate , contains three different fumarate ligands; each has a different coordination mode of the two COO groups. Nevertheless, its crystallography system and space group are monoclinic and P21/n, respectively, identical to those described above . The differences between our crystals and C12H20O19Ln2 are those reported above, which were caused by the method of preparation. Our crystals were obtained from water solution at ambient conditions, while the other ones were obtained by the hydrothermal method  or in an ethanol solution . The latter ways may lead to more condensed products with fewer water component molecules. The second difference is the ligand:ion molar ratio used in the reaction – we obtained our crystals with the 3:1 ratio, while the C12H20O19Ln2 crystals were obtained at the 3:2 ratio for the hydrothermal method.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0090" view="all">When comparing the crystal structure of lanthanide maleates  to the crystal structure of rare earth fumarates, one can notice that two hydrogen maleate ions by one O atom form the coordination bond to the Ln<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion, while there are six O atoms from carboxyl groups in the present fumarate complexes that are attached to each rare earth ion (see  and 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Also, the coordination modes of the carboxylate ions are different in both complexes. As is generally known, six coordinating fashions of the –COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion may be described . In lanthanide fumarate crystals, three of them occur: chelating-type bidentate, bridging bidentate, and tridentate chelating-bridging. In the rare earth maleate crystal, there was only one coordination form of the carboxyl ions – the monodentate type  . The careful analysis of the presented X-ray data makes it possible to consider the differences of the polarizability values (<ce:italic>α</ce:italic>) of oxygen atoms as ligating atoms, especially considering the type of the coordinating carboxyl ion. These kinds of O atoms should probably be at different places on the ordinal scale of covalency, what should be reflected in the spectroscopic properties of the investigated crystals . A comparison of the average Sm–O distance for both (maleate and fumarate) samarium compounds suggests that the character of the Ln–O bond (2.503<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) is more covalent for maleate than for fumarate (2.513<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (see ). Such a character of the Sm–O bond should be reflected in the spectroscopic properties of investigated crystals.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
When comparing the crystal structure of lanthanide maleates  to the crystal structure of rare earth fumarates, one can notice that two hydrogen maleate ions by one O atom form the coordination bond to the Ln3+ ion, while there are six O atoms from carboxyl groups in the present fumarate complexes that are attached to each rare earth ion (see  and 
). Also, the coordination modes of the carboxylate ions are different in both complexes. As is generally known, six coordinating fashions of the –COO− ion may be described . In lanthanide fumarate crystals, three of them occur: chelating-type bidentate, bridging bidentate, and tridentate chelating-bridging. In the rare earth maleate crystal, there was only one coordination form of the carboxyl ions – the monodentate type  . The careful analysis of the presented X-ray data makes it possible to consider the differences of the polarizability values (α) of oxygen atoms as ligating atoms, especially considering the type of the coordinating carboxyl ion. These kinds of O atoms should probably be at different places on the ordinal scale of covalency, what should be reflected in the spectroscopic properties of the investigated crystals . A comparison of the average Sm–O distance for both (maleate and fumarate) samarium compounds suggests that the character of the Ln–O bond (2.503Å) is more covalent for maleate than for fumarate (2.513Å) (see ). Such a character of the Sm–O bond should be reflected in the spectroscopic properties of investigated crystals.

<ce:para id="p0120" view="all">The emission spectrum recorded at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K shows a better resolution of the crystal-field fine structure and is similar to the spectrum recorded at room temperature. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0025"></ce:float-anchor> shows the energies of the <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">5-9/2</ce:inf> (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) transitions observed in the emission spectra of Sm(III) fumarate and maleate at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The transitions split at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K into the maximum number of (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2) crystal field components (see  and ) indicating a low symmetry of the Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion . For the <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>, <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">7/2</ce:inf>, and <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">9/2</ce:inf> transitions respectively three, four, and five main electronic components can be observed. This confirms the one low symmetry of the nearest neighbor of the lanthanide ion. The careful analysis of the low temperature emission spectra of the Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O crystal makes it possible to notice that some electronic components of <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>, <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">7/2</ce:inf>, and <ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>G<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">9/2</ce:inf> transitions demonstrate the double character with splitting of about 22<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. This kind of splitting can be attributed to ion-pair interactions . The fumarate ligands in the present structure act as bridges between Ln<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, thus giving rise to the chain structure. Such systems are very effective in ion-ion interactions and energy migration along the chain, which largely depends on the shortest intrachain Ln<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>–Ln<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> distances. The average distance between neighboring rare earth ions in the fumarate chain (4.28<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (see ) is smaller than 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Thus, Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions in these compounds can interact between each other through the “carboxylate bridges” of the fumarate anions, which is reflected in their spectra as the splitting of the crystal field components of f–f transitions. The determination of which components originate from ion–ion interactions needs additional investigations for fumarates concentrated and diluted by “innocent” ions (La<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, Ce<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, or Y<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>).</ce:para>

The fumarate ligands in the present structure act as bridges between Ln3+ ions, thus giving rise to the chain structure. Such systems are very effective in ion-ion interactions and energy migration along the chain, which largely depends on the shortest intrachain Ln3+–Ln3+ distances. The average distance between neighboring rare earth ions in the fumarate chain (4.28Å) (see ) is smaller than 5Å. Thus, Sm3+ ions in these compounds can interact between each other through the “carboxylate bridges” of the fumarate anions, which is reflected in their spectra as the splitting of the crystal field components of f–f transitions. The determination of which components originate from ion–ion interactions needs additional investigations for fumarates concentrated and diluted by “innocent” ions (La3+, Ce3+, or Y3+).

With the increasing of the overlap of the oxygen orbitals and the 4f orbitals (the nephelauxetic effect), the energy level structure of the lanthanide ion contracts and leads to a shift of hypersensitive bands towards longer wavelengths (the red shift). Such a shift was observed by us for the hypersensitive transition 6H5/2

<ce:section-title id="st055">IR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The IR spectra of the complexes are similar, and differ from the spectrum of the ligand. In the IR spectrum of fumaric acid, a broad intense peak from ∼3000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> to ∼2400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is observed, which corresponds to the O–H stretching vibrations of the dimeric structure of carboxylic acid. This peak is much more narrow and shifted for all of the complexes and can be observed from 4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> to 3000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which proves the Ln–O<ce:inf loc="post">(COO)</ce:inf> interactions. Furthermore, the peak at ∼920<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in fumaric acid (which disappears for the complexes) is significant for the dimeric structure and corresponds to O–H bending outside the plane vibrations . Peaks observed at ∼1600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (the stronger one) and 1400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (the weaker one) in the spectra of the complexes correspond to the carboxylic anion. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor> shows the comparison of IR spectra for Sm(III) fumarate and fumaric acid.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR spectra
The IR spectra of the complexes are similar, and differ from the spectrum of the ligand. In the IR spectrum of fumaric acid, a broad intense peak from ∼3000cm−1 to ∼2400cm−1 is observed, which corresponds to the O–H stretching vibrations of the dimeric structure of carboxylic acid. This peak is much more narrow and shifted for all of the complexes and can be observed from 4000cm−1 to 3000cm−1, which proves the Ln–O(COO) interactions. Furthermore, the peak at ∼920cm−1 in fumaric acid (which disappears for the complexes) is significant for the dimeric structure and corresponds to O–H bending outside the plane vibrations . Peaks observed at ∼1600cm−1 (the stronger one) and 1400 cm−1 (the weaker one) in the spectra of the complexes correspond to the carboxylic anion. 
 shows the comparison of IR spectra for Sm(III) fumarate and fumaric acid.

In the former three structures, there is one symmetry-independent Ln(III) cation, which adopts a 9-coordinate geometry with six oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups and three oxygen atoms from water molecules (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Sm, Eu, Nd). The Er (III) ion in the fumarate crystal, as the heavier rare-earth ion, is coordinated by eight oxygen atoms (six atoms from the fumarates and two atoms from water molecules). In all four crystals, three-dimensional polymeric structures are formed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
Eu and Nd fumarates are isostructural with Sm fumarate (space group 

P


1


¯



), but the Er analogue is different (space group P21/c). In the former three structures, there is one symmetry-independent Ln(III) cation, which adopts a 9-coordinate geometry with six oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups and three oxygen atoms from water molecules (Ln=Sm, Eu, Nd). The Er (III) ion in the fumarate crystal, as the heavier rare-earth ion, is coordinated by eight oxygen atoms (six atoms from the fumarates and two atoms from water molecules). In all four crystals, three-dimensional polymeric structures are formed.

In the absorption spectrum of Sm(III) fumarate, a shift to higher energy was observed for the hypersensitive transition 6H5/2
→
6F1/2. The calculated nephelauxetic ratio β and Sinha’s parameter σ suggested a decrease in the “degree of covalency” of the Sm–O bond from Sm maleate to Sm fumarate.
